title: How to Say Beautiful in Arabic

steps.title: Say "jameel" to refer to a male, or "jameela" to refer to a woman.
steps.content: Say "jameel" to refer to a male, or "jameela" to refer to a woman. In Arabic, this translates directly to "beautiful". Pronounce it "jah-meel" or "jah-meel-ah". The Arabic character is: جميل for masculine and جميلة for feminine. [1] X Research source Some Arabic speakers (e.g. Egyptians) tend to pronounce the word with a hard "G", as in "gah-meel" or "gah-meelah". How you pronounce the Arabic letter ج (Jim) might reveal the specific Arabic dialect you're learning. Don't worry too much about perfection. People will appreciate your effort. Pay close attention to native speakers and try to imitate their pronunciation. Bear in mind that "jameel" and "jameela" are only phonetic approximations of the Arabic word (جميل). There is one official way to spell these words in Arabic, but you may come across various acceptable English spellings: jamila, jameelah, gamila, gameela, etc. The important thing is that you know how to say it. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Understand that "beauty" in Arabic goes beyond physical appearance.
steps.content: Understand that "beauty" in Arabic goes beyond physical appearance. When Arabs say "jameel", mostly they mean more than just "good-looking." The terms "jameel" and "jameela" convey a deep, inner beauty, as in "there's something beautiful inside you."

steps.title: Say "Antee jameela" (female) or "Enta jameel" (male) to mean "you are beautiful".
steps.content: Say "Antee jameela" (female) or "Enta jameel" (male) to mean "you are beautiful". Pronounce it "an-tay jah-meelah" (female) or "enta jah-meel" (male). Be careful with your words. It's generally considered polite to avoid using overly familiar terms like "jameela" with women you don't know well, especially in formal settings. Consider the cultural context and the specific relationship. Call a woman "ya amar" (يا قمر) to mean "my moon" or "my most beautiful". Pronounce it "ya kamar". However, this is a more intimate and playful term, so use it with caution and only with someone you know well. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Note that "jameel" is also sometimes used to mean "good".
steps.content: Note that "jameel" is also sometimes used to mean "good". Say "hatha jameel" or "da gameel" if you like something and you think it is good or beautiful. Pronounce it "ha-thuh jah-meel". The "th" sound in "hatha" is similar to the "th" in "they" or "them". For inanimate objects, these words can be used to describe something truly exceptional, like a stunning sunset, a captivating piece of art, or a beautifully written poem. [4] X Research source
